1) I have a topic in Kafka called CustomerUpdateRequest.

2) Service C consumes that topic and updates Customers accordingly, e.g. updates a Customer's email address.

3) Service C has a StateStore of the Customer topic. This way it can do a quick check if e.g. the email hasn't already been set. Let's assume that if a customer's email is already set we don't allow it to be set again.

4) When Service C pushes a new message to the Customer topic with the updated email, the StateStore will take some time to update. If its not quick enough, another CustomerUpdateRequest for the same user may come in, and the service will not see that the email has already been set.

How can I make sure the StateStore doesn't have stale data?

One approach I have thought of is using store.put() to manually update the StateStore as soon as the service updates the customer. However I do not see many examples for this, so I'm not sure that is the best practice.

answers.title: Postgres multiple predicates on multiple columns

items.body_markdown:
Edited:

I thought I'd explain what I am trying to do so someone might have a better idea how to write the query better than what I was asking.


I've got a table that has about 500 million rows and another with about 50M rows.


The table definitions are like the following

```
CREATE TABLE NGRAM_CONTENT
(
    id  BIGINT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
    ref TEXT   NOT NULL,
    data      TEXT
);

CREATE INDEX idx_reference_ngram_content ON NGRAM_CONTENT (ref);
CREATE INDEX idx_id_ngram_content ON NGRAM_CONTENT (id);


CREATE TABLE NGRAMS
(
    id  BIGINT NOT NULL,
    ngram   TEXT   NOT NULL,
    ref TEXT   NOT NULL,
    name_length INT NOT NULL
);

CREATE INDEX combined_index ON NGRAMS (name_length, ngram, ref, id);
CREATE INDEX namelength_idx ON NGRAMS (name_length);
CREATE INDEX id_idx ON NGRAMS (id);
CREATE INDEX ref_idx ON NGRAMS (ref);
CREATE INDEX ngram_idx ON NGRAMS (ngram);

```

In order for fast insertion using bulk, upstream events that have been marked as deleted, are inserted with `null` for the data column of the NGRAM_CONTENT table and no foreign constraints have been setup, however
both `id` and `ref` from ngrams table are foreign keys to NGRAM_CONTENT table.


Some sample data 
```
Ngram_Content:
|id | ref  | data       |
| 1 | 'P1' | some_json  |
| 2 | 'P1' | some_new_json  | # P1 comes again as an update
| 3 | 'P2' | P3  | 
| 4 | 'P1' | null  | 

Ngrams: 

name_length | ngram | ref  | id |
12          | CH    | 'P1' | 1  |
12          | AN    | 'P1' | 1  |
14          | NEW   | 'P1' | 2  |
20          | CH    | 'P2' | 3  |
20          | CHAI  | 'P2' | 3  |
...
```
For the above data if I search for ngrams of 'CH' or 'AN' with id <= 1 then 
it will return `P1` with content `some_json` however if I search with id <= 2, then it won't match, as the latest at the `id=2` has been updated to `NEW` and if I search for `NEW` with id <= 5, then it'd return nothing too as the latest `P1` has been deleted.

All the searches should be done within a distance of `name_length` from and to.

In other words, only find the latest ngram content for a given `ref` that has not been deleted to a certain `id` within a limit of `name_length`

There are the 2 conditions that I need to support 
1. With an event id (for historical runs)
2. Without event id the use the latest 

So I came up with 2 variations like this

With event_id:

```
select w.* From NGRAM_CONTENT  w
inner join (
    select max(w.id) as w_max_event_id, w.ref from NGRAMS w
    inner join (
```

answers.body_markdown:
These parameters control how long the permissions & list of roles stay valid during the current session. It heavily dependent on your business requirements - if your application needs that roles & permissions could be changed "online" during work, then you need to have lower values, if it's ok to have the same roles & permissions until next reconnect/restart of app, then you can go to higher values.

But you can also have a combination of both, if you'll use `roles_update_interval_in_ms`, `credentials_update_interval_in_ms` & `permissions_update_interval_in_ms` to lower values than `roles_validity_in_ms`, `credentials_interval_in_ms`, and `permissions_interval_in_ms` (see [doc][1]). If these values are specified, then roles, permissions & credentials will be checked in background in given intervals, and if request succeeds, then the cache will be updated, and if it fails, then cached value still will be used.  For example, you can set `roles_validity_in_ms` to 1 day, and `roles_update_interval_in_ms` to 10 minutes, so you'll able to relatively quickly react to changes in the roles for given user.


  [1]: https://docs.datastax.com/en/archived/cassandra/3.0/cassandra/configuration/configCassandra_yaml.html#configCassandra_yaml__roles_update_interval_in_ms
answers.title: Imact of increasing roles_validity_in_ms & permissions_validity_in_ms

answers.body_markdown:
This is actually a bug in PHP (I'm yet to find its ID in the bugtracker) that has been fixed with PHP 7.4 - [see here](https://3v4l.org/jZGhQ).

`print_r` is one of a few ways to display internals of an object, including its private properties. Apparently, before PHP 7.4, calling `print_r` on an object caused its properties to become public (presumably using reflections, so that their contents could be displayed), but never turned back after that.

[The documentation](https://www.php.net/manual/en/class.datetime.php) does not name `\DateTime::$date` as a public field. If you want to display date, use [`\DateTime::format()`](https://www.php.net/manual/en/datetime.format.php) method instead.

`tf.assign*` functions are available as methods on [`tf.Variable`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Variable) in TF 2.0. So, your example could be rewritten as

```
with tf.GradientTape() as gtape:
    ...
    W.assign_sub(learning_rate * gradients)
```

Note that unlike `tf.assign` in TF 1.X, [`tf.Variable.assing_sub`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Variable#assign_sub) will execute the assignment eagerly.

answers.body_markdown:
Probably the easiest way to achieve what you want is with `git log` or `git diff`, as both can take rev range and path:

    git log [<options>] [<revision range>] [[--] <path>…​]
    git diff [<options>] <commit> <commit> [--] [<path>…​]


For example, to test if the latest commit touches directory1 and/or directory2, you can use:

    git log --oneline HEAD^..HEAD directory1 directory2

For negative match, exclude pathspec should do the trick:

    git log --oneline HEAD^..HEAD -- '.' ':(exclude)./directory1'

Or similarly with diff:

    git diff HEAD^..HEAD '.' ':(exclude)directory'

answers.title: Do Postgres multicolumn indexes get used for OR queries?

answers.body_markdown:
One option is to create a GIN index on the array of the columns, then use an array operator:

    create index on title using gin (array[name1,name2,name3,name4]);

Then use 

    SELECT * 
    FROM title 
    WHERE array[name1,name2,name3,name4] @> array['foo'];

Note that a GIN index is a bit more expensive to maintain than a BTree index.
answers.title: Do Postgres multicolumn indexes get used for OR queries?

answers.body_markdown:
Having index on `(col1, col2, col3, etc)` it will be used for conditions/ordering on `col1`, or `col1` and `col2`, or `col1`, `col2` and `col3` etc. It will be not used for conditions/ordering only on `col3` for example.

Look at this:

    # create table t as select random() as a, random() as b from generate_series(1,1000000);
    # create index i on t(a,b);
    # analyze t;
    # explain analyze select * from t where a > 0.9;
                                                          QUERY PLAN                                                       
    -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
     Bitmap Heap Scan on t  (cost=2246.83..8863.15 rows=96826 width=16) (actual time=10.973..28.023 rows=99311 loops=1)
       Recheck Cond: (a > '0.9'::double precision)
       Heap Blocks: exact=5406
       ->  Bitmap Index Scan on i  (cost=0.00..2222.62 rows=96826 width=0) (actual time=10.251..10.252 rows=99311 loops=1)
             Index Cond: (a > '0.9'::double precision)
     Planning Time: 0.348 ms
     Execution Time: 31.054 ms
    
     # explain analyze select * from t where b > 0.9;
                                                    QUERY PLAN                                                
    ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
     Seq Scan on t  (cost=0.00..17906.00 rows=99117 width=16) (actual time=0.015..70.505 rows=100137 loops=1)
       Filter: (b > '0.9'::double precision)
       Rows Removed by Filter: 899863
     Planning Time: 0.090 ms
     Execution Time: 73.656 ms

However when you are using `or` condition the DBMS actually should to perform several queries, for our example `select * from t where a > 0.9 or b > 0.9` is equal to `select * from t where a > 0.9` (index could be used) and `select * from t where b > 0.9` (index could not be used) thus instead of two actions (scan index then scan whole table) DBMS performs only one action (scan whole table)

Hope it explains why your index is not used for your query.
answers.title: Do Postgres multicolumn indexes get used for OR queries?

answers.body_markdown:
The error you're encountering is at `std::regex place = "(place)\\s[ROYGBP][0-5]\\s(at)\\s[A-Z][0-9]{1,2}";` - I believe it happens because that's not correct syntax for initializing a regex. Try this instead:

`std::regex place = std::regex("(place)\\s[ROYGBP][0-5]\\s(at)\\s[A-Z][0-9]{1,2}");`

Be sure you're compiling with the `--std=c++11` (or higher) flag; otherwise, the compiler is going to get frustrated with you! According to [cppreference.com][1], this functionality wasn't added until C++11. The site also has great resources on the syntax for regex; it's what I used to build my regex projects.


  [1]: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/regex
answers.title: How to use Regex in C++

answers.body_markdown:
(This answer is based on a [deleted answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/58233561/509868) by the user [VTT](https://stackoverflow.com/users/7860670/vtt))

`std::regex` constructor taking a single pointer to char argument is `explicit` so it can not be invoked using copy initialization syntax. Use direct list initialization syntax instead:

```
std::regex place{"(place)\\s[ROYGBP][0-5]\\s(at)\\s[A-Z][0-9]{1,2}"};
```

Or use the same constructor but change the syntax so it permits `explicit` initialization:

```
std::regex place("(place)\\s[ROYGBP][0-5]\\s(at)\\s[A-Z][0-9]{1,2}");
```
answers.title: How to use Regex in C++

answers.body_markdown:
To create a temporary table in MySQL, you would use:

    CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE local  (  
        User_id int,  
        User_name varchar(50),  
        User_address varchar(150)  
    ) ;

The convention that temporary tables start with '#' is specific to SQL Server (and Sybase).  In most databases, you use the `temporary` keyword for this purpose.

To create another table from an existing table, you use `CRAETE TABLE AS`.  This is so much part of SQL, that the operation is sometimes referred to as CTAS.  Once again, SQL Server (and Sybase) uses the `INTO` syntax.  In many databases, `INTO` is used for variable assignment.

answers.body_markdown:
You could adjust the **width** and the **height** parameter of the plot:

    df.hvplot.scatter(x='lat', y='lon', width=500, height=500)


Or do you mean the range of the axes? They can be set by parameter **xlim** and **ylim**, for example:

    df.hvplot.scatter(x='lat', y='lon', xlim=(6, 8), ylim=(45, 47))

Since you're plotting latitudes and longitudes you should definitely take a look at geoviews: [http://geoviews.org/][1]


  [1]: http://geoviews.org/
answers.title: How to set up scaled axes with hvplot?

answers.body_markdown:
`SwiftUI` doesn't have 32 bit header, so adding architecture flag where the error is fix the issue

```
#if (arch(x86_64) || arch(arm64))
//...
#endif
```
answers.title: How to use SwiftUI in framework

answers.body_markdown:
You can wrap SwiftUI related code in `#if canImport(SwiftUI) && canImport(Combine)` statements. See [example][1]. 


  [1]: https://github.com/ruuvi/com.ruuvi.station.ios/blob/dev/station/Classes/Presentation/Modules/Settings/Submodules/Daemons/View/SwiftUI/DaemonsEnvironmentObject.swift
answers.title: How to use SwiftUI in framework
